is a small village located at milepost 66.8 on the Taylor Highway in

. It is one of the only places along this highway where gas is available, and is therefore a popular rest stop.  Local legend is that the town was named after a group of miners decided to name it Ptarmigan after the local birds, but unable to agree on the spelling finally decided "Hell, let's just call it Chicken" (the nickname for ptarmigan).

The vast majority of visitors will arrive by car along the gravel Taylor Highway.  The road is not maintained year-round, so travel by road may be impossible once snow falls.  The town also has a small dirt runway (
) located 0.8 miles east of the highway that is accessible to private planes year-round.

value: hours=leaves Tok 12:30 Tu Fr, arrives Chicken 13:00, leaves 13:15 for Tok
content=Twice-weekly airline service to Chicken International Airport with flag stops at Eagle and Boundary. Price includes 30 lbs baggage per passenger.

There are 3 businesses in Chicken: "Chicken Gold Camp & Outpost", "Downtown Chicken" and the "Goldpanner". The first two are located a short distance off of the highway on the Airport Road spur road.  The Goldpanner gift shop is located along the Taylor highway.

Given the town's small size (the official population was 38 in 2002) the most obvious way to get around is by foot. Those unwilling to walk the short distances between the town's three businesses may want to ask themselves what they're doing in the wilds of Alaska!

value: directions=located at the Chicken Gold Camp/Chicken Creek Outpost

content=This gold dredge operated on Chicken Creek from 1959 until 1967, and was previously used on Pedro Creek outside of Fairbanks.  The Pedro Dredge is a National Historic Site and is open to daily tours. It is one of the most complete Alaska gold dredges, an example of the type of equipment used to mine the area's gold deposits.

. Abandoned 1920's schoolhouse originally run by teacher Anne Hobbs Purdy, author of "Tisha: The Story of a Young Teacher in the Alaska Wilderness" (1976) and "Dark Boundary" (1954). Tours 9am and 2pm daily (summer only) from Goldpanner to the town and schoolhouse.

$10 to $50/day for mining activities and $30 for 1/2 day kayak rentals. Gold panning and recreational mining are provided on their claims for daily fees. Rental equipment, kayaking adventures on the nearby Fortymile River.

content=Two-day annual gathering of global ‘chickenites” and ‘chickenuts’ and local bluegrass music, mid-June, since 2007. Pack up your ‘nest’, ‘comb’ your feathers and come ‘strut’ your stuff in the midnight sun.
offers recreational gold panning on their claim on Chicken Creek.
name=Chicken Creek Café, Saloon and Mercantile Emporium
content=T-shirts, postcards, jewellery, furs, souvenirs, ice cream, soda, coffee, fudge, gas, diesel, wi-fi.
Pies, buffalo burgers, reindeer bratwurst, potato salad and baked wild Alaskan salmon.
Café with fresh baked scones, egg soufflés, deli style paninis, soup du jour, BBQ chicken, ice cream, espresso and other beverage concoctions.
. Best bar in town. Only bar in town.

content=Campground beside Chicken Creek, picnic pavilion, BBQ pits, wi-fi, firewood. Store with local gold jewellery, ice cream, t-shirts, fuel station. 3-hole golf course, walking tours thru historical Chicken, goldpanning.
price=camping: $18/night with hookup, $10/night without, lodging: $90/night cabins (double occupancy), $75/night rooms (double occupancy)

content=Camping on 20 sites with hookups and amenities including free wireless internet, free firewood, dump station, potable water and access to public restrooms and pay-showers. Offers cabins for up to six or rooms with two single beds, propane heat, free wireless internet, kitchenettes, and access to public restrooms and pay-showers.

There is one small post office in Chicken, Alaska 99732 which receives mail twice weekly. As Chicken is off the grid, there is no telephone exchange or other utility service in the area. Any Internet access, presumably, is via satellite.

- One of the most famous and historic gold mining towns in the North, Dawson City is located 108 miles away along the Taylor and Top of the World highways.
